data.title: George Gershwin
data.meta_description: News about George Gershwin, including commentary and archival articles published in The New York Times.
data.text:
john mcwhorter

No, ‘Rhapsody in Blue’ Is Not ‘the Worst’

A defense of Gershwin’s masterpiece on the occasion of its centennial.

By John McWhorter

letters

The Lyrical Century of ‘Rhapsody in Blue’

Musicians write about George Gershwin’s masterpiece. Also: A move to impeach the homeland secretary; healing; slavery in France; restaurant menus.

The Worst Masterpiece: ‘Rhapsody in Blue’ at 100

A jazz musician considers the legacy and unfulfilled promise of George Gershwin’s catchy — or you could say corny — repertory staple.

By Ethan Iverson

Review: The Philadelphia Orchestra Revels, and Struggles, in Jazz

At Carnegie Hall, a program of Stravinsky, Weill and freely improvised Gershwin highlighted a dialogue between jazz and classical music.

By Anastasia Tsioulcas

New York Today

A Musical Walk With Gershwin, Rachmaninoff and Papageno

The Dutch baritone Thomas Oliemans visits the haunts of great composers. And the air clears, just a little.

By James Barron

John McWhorter

The Black Musical That May Have Inspired Gershwin

You probably haven’t heard of 1921’s ‘Shuffle Along,’ but its Broadway influence can’t be overlooked.

By John McWhorter

nonfiction

What Makes a Popular Song Great?

Rob Kapilow’s “Listening for America” explains how to distinguish good from bad in the Great American Songbook.

By Todd S. Purdum

‘Porgy and Bess’ Can Offend. Now Try Translating It Into Spanish.

Minefields abound when translating outdated, sometimes derogatory dialect for the Metropolitan Opera’s seatback titles.

By Eric Grode

Critic’s Pick

Review: A Splendid ‘Porgy and Bess’ Opens the Met Opera Season

As the title characters, Eric Owens and Angel Blue give one of the finest performances of their careers.

By Anthony Tommasini
